review: I had a Chromecast before, but this Fire Stick does a lot of things the Chromecast does not (HBO Go, Amazon Prime, and more). I also prefer the ease of using the remote (vs the Chromecast which is primarily controlled from your mobile device). It is worth paying a little more for a Fire Stick because it can do so much more. All in all, a great product. I definitely don't miss my cable anymore.The downsides? While I still consider it the better device, I don't like the following:1) I have noticed the video sometimes freezes and then has to catch up with the audio. My Chromecast never did that.2) On my tiny television, I sometimes can't read the text on the Netflix app without getting closer to the screen. And I have good vision (no glasses or contacts).  This would not be a problem on a larger screen, though.
author: S.H.D.

review: Unlike the Chromecast, it pops up errors if you don't connect it to wall power - well guess what, i don't have wall power anywhere near where I need to plug it in. If it can't work by drawing 3-5V off the USB port right beside it then what's the point? This is supposed to be a device that is portable - bad engineering design. The menuing is OK, the UI is a bit basic but it's usable and gets the job done. I don't much use this as it's not enticed me enough to ditch the Roku, but it's nice to have as a backup.
author: Troy Engel

review: The Fire Stick performs exactly as expected. It is intended to replace my Roku. The Roku has an IR user interface and has always been a source of agrevation to me since you must position the remote directly in front of the unit for it to respond. I appreciate the radio interface on my Fire Stick since it can even work when it is located out of view from the control unit. The set-up was easy and I have since bought 2 more Fire Sticks for my other TV's.
